msDesc.head: Composite manuscript in nine parts, including poetic anthologies (Parts B, F, G, H and I), as well as theological and pastoral texts. The volume includes poems by Hildebert of Lavardin, Marbod of Rennes and Bernard Silvestris as well as the Song of Songs, and texts by Anselm and Martin of Braga. Some similarities in script, mise-en-page and decoration suggest a common origin (possibly a common scribe) for the poetic anthologies.

physDesc.p: Composite manuscript: fols. 1-26 (Part A) || fols. 27-57 (Part B) || fols. 58-69 (Part C) || fols. 70-83 (Part D) || fols. 84-93 (Part E) || fols. 94-109 (Part F) || fols. 110-116 (Part G) || fols. 117-123 (Part H) || fols. 124-133 (Part I)

supportDesc.extent: v (i-iv are paper; v is a parchment leaf) + 133 leaves + ii (paper)
supportDesc.foliation: Foliation in pencil. The first parchment leaf is blank and foliated as v. The two final paper flyleaves are foliated 134 and 135.

binding.p: Medieval sewing supports. Seventeenth-century laced-case limp parchment binding; the cover is now partly detached.

history.provenance: William Laud (1573–1645). Inscribed, ‘Liber Guilielmi Laud Archiepiscopi Cantuarij et Cancellarij Vniuersitatis Oxoniensis 1634’ (fol. 1r, lower margin).
history.acquisition: Bodleian Library: first donation from Laud, 22 May 1635 (A Summary Catalogue of Western Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library at Oxford, vol. 1, ed. R. W. Hunt (Oxford, 1953), pp. 129-130). Former Bodleian shelfmark 'C.2' (fol. i verso and fol. iv verso). In 1641, the Laudian MSS were arranged in eleven compartments, lettered A-L: see A Summary Catalogue of Western Manuscripts in the Bodleian Library at Oxford, vol. 2 part 1, ed. F. Madan and H. H. E. Craster (Oxford, 1922), p. 14. Fol. iv verso: an early modern table of contents ('In hoc m.s. continentur (...)').

listBibl.bibl: A. B. Scott, 'The Poems of Hildebert of Le Mans: A New Examination of the Canon', Mediaeval and Renaissance Studies 6 (1968), pp. 42-83 at p. 49.
A. G. Rigg, 'Medieval Latin Poetic Anthologies (IV)', Medieval Studies 43 (1981), pp. 472-497, at p. 477.
A. G. Rigg, A History of Anglo-latin Literature (Cambridge, 1992), pp. 150-151.
Thomas Hayes, Das Lateinische Lehrgedicht im Mittelalter (Leiden, New York, Köln, 1997), pp. 274-275 and 320-321.

msPart.head: A twelfth-century copy of the Song of Songs, with later additions of theological and pastoral texts

msItem.title: Song of Songs
msItem.incipit: Osculetur me osculo oris sui
msItem.explicit: ceruorum super montes aromatum.

msItem.author: Anselm
msItem.title: Meditatio I
msItem.incipit: Terret me uita mea
msItem.explicit: qui cum deo patre et spiritu sancto gloriaris per interminata secula. Amen.
msItem.bibl: Edited in: Sancti Anselmi Opera, 6 vols., ed. F. S. Schmitt (Edinburgh, 1946–61), 3:3, pp. 76-79.

msItem.author: Martin of Braga
msItem.title: Formula uitae honestae, extract (1a - 2 (line 21))
msItem.incipit: Quatuor uirtutum species multorum sapientum sentenciis diffinite sunt
msItem.explicit: animo tuo cuncta propone
msItem.bibl: Edited in: La Formvla vitae honestae de Martín de Braga y el Libro de las cuatro virtudes de Alfonso de Cartagena, ed. and trans. L. Ranero Riestra (Pisa, 2021), which lists previous editions. The manuscript is listed (no. 67), but the extract of the Formula uitae honestae at fols. 15r-16r is not identified (only the extract beginning at fol. 58v is identified).

msItem.title: Text on Ps. 83,5
msItem.incipit: Beati qui habitant in domo tua domine
msItem.explicit: labore qui autem presentem

msItem.author: Melito, Saint, Bishop of Sardis
msItem.title: Transitus Mariae, version B2
msItem.rubric: Incipit narracio de assumpcione beate uirginis marie
msItem.incipit: Sanctus mellito de assumpcione gloriose dei genitricis que a beato
Melito seruus Christi ecclesie sardiensis
msItem.explicit: pariter in triumpho. Qui vivit et regnat in secula seculorum. Amen.
msItem.bibl: Edited in: M. Haibach-Reinisch, Ein neuer 'Transitus Mariae' des Pseudo-Melito (Rome, 1962), pp. 63-87 (manuscript O1).

msItem.title: Text on the Virgin Mary
msItem.note: The text (with minor variants) is found in Pietro di Ripalta's Chronica placentina.
msItem.incipit: Beata uirgo maria mater domini duodecim annorum fuit quando per spiritum sanctum angelo nuntiante concepit
msItem.explicit: uixit autem beata uirgo maria annis xx in domo beati
msItem.bibl: Edited in: Pietro da Ripalta, Chronica placentina nella trascrizione di Iacopo Mori (Ms. Pallastrelli 6), ed. M Fillìa and C. Binello (Piacenza, 1995), pp. 33-34.
msItem.note: Fol. 26 is blank, save for a later addition in an early modern hand (a reference to the 1555 Basel edition of Marbod of Rennes' Liber lapidum, a copy of which is found at fol. 27r).

objectDesc.collation: 18 (fols. 2-8), 24+4 (the fifth to eighth leaves are added singleton leaves) (fols. 9-16), 310 (fols. 17-26)

layoutDesc.layout: Quires 1 and 2: 1 col., 17 lines, double vertical bounding lines on each side of the text. c. 83 5+55+5 Ruled in leadpoint. Written above the top ruled line.
Quire 3: 1 col., 22 lines, single vertical bounding lines. c. 85 × 60 mm. Ruled in leadpoint. Written above the top ruled line.

handDesc.handNote: Fols. 10r-16v: Additions in several early Gothic hands, sometimes irregular, with elements of documentary handwriting.
Fols. 17r-20v: An irregular Gothic bookhand executed with a thick nib. A few elongated descenders on the final lines of pages.
Fol. 25v: An addition in an informal Gothic hand. A blank space is left at the beginning of the text for an initial, which was not inserted ('[B]eata').

decoDesc.decoNote: Four-line painted green and red 'arabesque' initial (fol. 1r) (Pächt and Alexander, vol. 3, p. 15, no. 125: 'British school').
Red initials with green penwork (fols. 10r and 16v).
Blue, green or red initials with penwork in red or blue (fols. 17r-20r).

history.origin: 12th century, first half; additions, 13th century, early (fols. 10v-16v), and 13th century, middle (fols. 17r-25v)England (?)

msItem.author: Marbode, Bishop of Rennes
msItem.title: Liber lapidum
msItem.rubric: Incipit libellus de nominibus et naturis et locis lapidum
msItem.incipit: Euax rex arabum
msItem.explicit: Que decies senis distincta patent capitellis.

msItem.title: Computistical verses
msItem.incipit: Sciendum quod post xvi kalendas februarias ubi luna fuerit x, ibi terminus lxx
msItem.explicit: Post viii idus maii ubi luna iiii in terminus pentecostes.
msItem.note: Verses also found in MS. Auct. D.4.6, fol. vi verso.

msItem.title: Verses on the canonical hours
msItem.incipit: Cantatur prima, sumebas christe flagella
msItem.explicit: In media nocte baratr' spoliauerit ipse
msItem.bibl: Chevalier, Rep. Hymn., vol. 3, no. 24248 (citing only this manuscript).

msItem.title: Verses on the three marriages of St Anne
msItem.incipit: Anna uiro Iohachim genuit te uirgo maria
msItem.explicit: Sic \tribus/ anna uiris genuit tres una (sic) marias.

listBibl.bibl: Edited with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1423.
Chevalier, Rep. Hymn., vol. 3, no. 23010. See also vol. 1, no. 1113 ('Anna viro Joachim peperit te virgo Maria').
A variant of WIC 1067 ('Anna viro Joachim peperit te virgo Maria').
Variants of this poem are discussed in G. Dinkova-Bruun, 'The Three Marriages of St Anne: Poems from Engelberg, Stiftsbibliothek 117', Mediaeval Studies 81 (2019), pp. 1-27.

For a list of manuscripts with the poem beg. 'Anna viro Joachim peperit te virgo Maria': Salome and the kin of Jesus. The treatises of Maurice of Kirkham and Herbert of Bosham, ed. and trans. C. J. Mews et al. (Toronto, 2024), p. 190.

msItem.title: Treatise on the figures of speech and tropes
msItem.incipit: Est barbarismus uerbi corruptio uilis
msItem.explicit: Antismos lepide subsannat sed sine felle.
msItem.note: A further line of text was added after four blank lines: 'Per casus uariat uerbum polinthethon unde'.

listBibl.bibl: Bursill-Hall, Census, no. 188.123

msItem.author: Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours (attrib.)
msItem.title: De malicia saeculi siue De peccato originali
msItem.incipit: Tot scelerum morbis totus prope subiacet orbis
msItem.explicit: Falsa que iustificat, iustaque falsificat.
msItem.note: Only the first 22 verses are included.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: B. Hauréau, Les mélanges poétiques d'Hildebert de Lavardin (Paris, 1882), p. 337.
Chevalier, Rep. Hymn., vol. 4, no. 41266.
R. Newhauser, I. Bejczy, A Supplement to Morton W. Bloomfield et al., 'Incipits of Latin Works on the Virtues and Vices, 1100-1500 A.D.' (Turnhout, 2008), no. 6025.

msItem.title: De excidio Troiae versus
msItem.incipit: Uiribus arte minis danaum data troia ruinis
msItem.explicit: Et gens romulea surgit ab hectorea.

listBibl.bibl: Edited with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1451 and in The Oxford Book of Medieval Latin Verse, ed. S. Gaselee (Oxford, 1946), p. 121, no. 65.

msItem.author: Bernard Silvestris
msItem.title: Cosmographia
msItem.rubric: [lost through cropping; the final word is partly visible: 'siluestris']

msItem.title: Cosmographia, extract (Book I, 3, vv. 37-60)
msItem.incipit: Preiacet in stellis series quam longior usus
msItem.explicit: Flectit, et eternum uoluere stare fuit

msItem.explicit: Iuniperus, teteri semine pene piper.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Bernardus Silvestris, Cosmographia, ed. P. Dronke (Leiden, 1978), p. 111.
WIC 742.

msItem.rubric: Genere aeriuagum [heading, not in red ink]

A variant edited in: Neues Archiv 18 (1893), p. 516.

msItem.title: Riddle
msItem.incipit: Nomen habens Ade flos

msItem.title: Cosmographia, extract (Book II, 10)
msItem.incipit: Pignora cara dee, quas ante creata creauit
msItem.explicit: Preueniens stelle signa locumque sue.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Bernardus Silvestris, Cosmographia, ed. P. Dronke (Leiden, 1978), pp. 140-142.

msItem.title: Cosmographia, extract (Book II, 14: vv. 175-178)
msItem.incipit: Longe disparibus causis mutandus in horas
msItem.explicit: Sudat in hoc uitam denichilatque dies.
msItem.note: Text added in the lower margin at fol. 55v.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Bernardus Silvestris, Cosmographia, ed. P. Dronke (Leiden, 1978), pp. 155.

msItem.author: Bernard Silvestris
msItem.title: Cosmographia, extract (Book II, 14: vv. 1-18, 133-152, 161-170)
msItem.rubric: Idem post multa [title, but not rubricated]
msItem.incipit: Cuditur artifici circumspectoque politu
msItem.explicit: Ut simili genesis ore reducat auos.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Bernardus Silvestris, Cosmographia, ed. P. Dronke (Leiden, 1978), pp. 150-154.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 20-21 lines. Ruled in leadpoint. Written above the top ruled line. Pricking in inner margin (quire 4) and outer margin (quire 7). Irregular ruling pattern (with double vertical bounding lines on the left and a single bounding line on the right or no bounding line on the right or, in some cases, double vertical bounding lines on both sides of the text). c. 90 6+49 (fol. 27r).

handDesc.handNote: Early Gothic hands, sometimes irregular, with varying degrees of documentary influence, such as elongated ascenders and descenders, or the stylised treatment below the baseline of the letters 'f', 'q', 's', and sometimes 'r'.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red initials with green or red penwork (the penwork may be a later addition). Some guide letters.

msPart.head: Martin of Braga's Formula uitae honestae

msItem.author: Martin of Braga
msItem.title: Formula uitae honestae (extract)
msItem.rubric: Incipit libellus Martini episcopi ad Milonem regem Gallicie. De quatuor uirtutibus cardinalibus
msItem.incipit: Quatuor uirtutum species multorum sapiencium sentenciis diffinite sunt
msItem.explicit: deficientem contempnat ingnauiam.
msItem.bibl: Edited in: La Formvla vitae honestae de Martín de Braga y el Libro de las cuatro virtudes de Alfonso de Cartagena, ed. and trad. L. Ranero Riestra (Pisa, 2021), which lists previous editions. The manuscript is listed (no. 67).
msItem.note: Fols. 67-69 (the end of the eighth quire) are blank.

extent.note: Rubrics and headings sometimes cropped in the top margin.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 23 lines. Ruled in leadpoint. Pricking on outer and lower margins. First line of text below the top ruled line. Double vertical bounding lines on both sides of the text, ruled space c. 73 3+50+3

decoDesc.decoNote: Blue and red painted initials, with alternating red or green penwork. Some guide letters.

msPart.head: An aid to confession in Anglo-Norman and a commentary on patristic texts in Latin (now incomplete)

msItem.title: Interrogatory for examining conscience, in prose
msItem.rubric: Ici comence le penitencer (...) De orguil [party erased]
msItem.incipit: Les especes de orguil
msItem.note: Imperfect at the end (one or several central bifolia are likely to be missing from the ninth quire which now only has two leaves (fols. 70-71)).

bibl.ref: JONAS: Répertoire des textes et des manuscrits médiévaux d'oc et d'oïl

listBibl.bibl: Dean & Boulton, p. 362, no. 661.

msItem.title: Extracts of patristic texts and commentary
msItem.incipit: De paucitate saluandorum. Bernardus. Ne mireris ut in multitudine uocatorum paucitas inueniatur electorum
msItem.explicit: cum bonis temporalibus replerentur.
msItem.note: Perhaps imperfect at the end (what seems to be a catchword at the bottom of fol. 83v is not matched with the following quire, suggesting that at least one quire following the tenth quire may now be lost).

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 26 lines. Ruled in leadpoint. Pricking on outer margin. First line of text above or below the top ruled line. Fol. 70: single vertical bounding lines, c. 77 x 60 mm. Fols. 71-83: double vertical bounding lines on both sids of the text, c. 72 4+55+3

handDesc.handNote: Fol. 70: a small Gothic bookhand. Fols. 71-83: a small Gothic bookhand. Some of the ascenders on the top lines and descenders on the bottom lines are elongated.

decoDesc.decoNote: Fol. 70: red painted initials, with green penwork.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: Miserere mei deus secundum magnam misericordiam tuam
msItem.explicit: qui in trinitate perfecta uiuis et regnas deus per omnia secula seculorum amen.
msItem.note: The text follows the structure of Augustine, Enarrationes in Psalmos, Ps. 50,6.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: Sancta maria immaculata uirgo
msItem.explicit: facias collocari qui es benedictus in secula seculorum amen.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: Domine ihesu christe esto michi peccatori
msItem.explicit: ut diebus ac noctibus te merear semper habere in mente amen.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: O pietatis dulcedo domine
msItem.explicit: in die resurrectionis resurgere per te ihesu christe saluator mundi qui cum deo patre et spiritu sancto uiuit et regnat in unitate spiritus sancti deus per omnia secula seculorum amen.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: Adoro te domine Ihesu christe deus eterne
msItem.explicit: digneris me iustificare in te et per te saluator mundi qui cum deo patre

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: O beata Dei genitrix Maria
msItem.explicit: peccatorum meorum remissionem merear accipere per eundem.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: Deus qui nobis signatis lumine uultus
msItem.explicit: ad faciem uenientem super nos iudicem securi uideamus. dominum nostrum ihesum christum filium tuum.
msItem.bibl: Edited in: Horae Eboracenses, ed. C. Wordsworth, Surtees Society 132 (Durham and London, 1920), p. 175; U. M. Lang, 'Votive Masses of the Holy Face of Christ in Early Printed Diocesan Missals', Mediaeval Studies 79 (2017), pp. 165-203, at p. 166.
msItem.note: Later medieval notes in lower margin at fol. 91v, now erased.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: Deus qui pro redemptione humani generis
msItem.explicit: et remissionem omnium peccatorum nostrorum qui cum deo patre et spiritu sancto uiuit et regnat deus per omnia secula seculorum. Amen.
msItem.note: Later medieval notes added in the blank space at the end of fol. 92v, including mnemonic verses on impediments to marriage (inc.: 'error, condicio, uotum, cognatio, crimen'; Walther, Proverbia (nov. ser.), 7175).

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 25-6 lines. Ruled in leadpoint. Pricking on outer and lower margins. First line of text above or below the top ruled line. Double vertical bounding lines on both sides of the text, with variations. Ruled space c. 78 2+52+3 (fol. 85r: c. 76 x 2+48+2 mm.).

decoDesc.decoNote: Red and blue painted initials, with green or red penwork.

msItem.incipit: Occumbunt fixi iaculo, mucrone, sagitta
msItem.explicit: Ore rufinus, athis corpore, sceua coma.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Anthologia latina: sive poesis latinae supplementum. Pars prior: Carmina in codicibus scripta, Fasc. II, ed. A. Riese (Leipzig, 1870), pp. lxiv-lxv.

msItem.title: Epigram
msItem.incipit: Cum de latrina lapsum Salomona ruina
msItem.explicit: Plaudit et ipse iubet, cras ut ibi recubet.
msItem.bibl: WIC 3580. See also WIC 4852 ('Dum de latrina lapsum Salomonem ruina').

msItem.title: Rufus and Corinna (poem)
msItem.incipit: Ruffe, doles et flere soles quod pulcra Corinna
msItem.explicit: Negligitur – nec te patitur – tua forma placere.
msItem.bibl: A. G. Rigg, ‘Medieval Latin Poetic Anthologies (I)’, Mediaeval Studies 39 (1977), no. 44a, p. 304.
msItem.note: The text is also found in MS. Rawl. G. 109. Full transcription of the text in the online description of MS. Rawl. G. 109 (no. 49).

msItem.incipit: An doleam flens propter eam uir lumine casse
msItem.explicit: Non potuit, nec digna fuit, iungi meliori.
msItem.bibl: A. G. Rigg, ‘Medieval Latin Poetic Anthologies (I)’, Mediaeval Studies 39 (1977), no. 44b, p. 304.
msItem.note: The text is also found in MS. Rawl. G. 109. Full transcription of the text in the online description of MS. Rawl. G. 109 (no. 49).

msItem.incipit: Est hodie locus inuidie uirtutis egestas
msItem.explicit: descipitur, dolet, arguitur, perit omnis honestas

listBibl.bibl: A closely related variant is included in a poem on the interdict of England, by Geoffrey of Vinsauf edited in: M. Camargo, 'Geoffrey of Vinsauf's Memorial verses', Nottingham Medieval Studies 56 (2012), pp. 81-119, at p. 114 (poem no. 9: 'On the Tribute of England (2)', vv. 7-8) and E. Faral, Les arts poétiques du XIIe et du XIIIe siècle (Paris, 1924), pp. 24-26, at p. 26.
WIC 5681. The verses are also found in Saint-Omer, Bibliothèque d’Agglomération du Pays de Saint-Omer, MS. 142, fol. 174v.

msItem.incipit: Queritur omnibus a sapientibus artis honestas
msItem.explicit: Sed placet omnibus insipientibus artis egestas.
msItem.bibl: Edited in: J. Werner, Lateinische Sprichwörter und Sinnsprüche des Mittelalters (Heidelberg, 1912), no. 57 p. 76.

msItem.incipit: Ille nocet qui uera docet, uelud insidiator
msItem.explicit: Ille placet qui uera tacet tamquam famulator
msItem.bibl: A variant of Walther, Proverbia (nov. ser.), 11456.

msItem.incipit: Perniciosior et capitalior est inimicus
msItem.explicit: Qui studiosior et specialior hesit amicus.
msItem.bibl: Edited in: J. Werner, Beiträge zur Kunde der lateinische Literatur des Mittelalters (Aarau, 1905), p. 21, no. 32.

msItem.incipit: Prudens prudenti, stultus placet insipienti
msItem.bibl: Walther, Proverbia (nov. ser.), 22789.

msItem.incipit: Perfidus et nequam rem iustam dampnat et equam
msItem.bibl: Same beginning as Walther, Proverbia (nov. ser.), 21351.

msItem.incipit: Quam prauus mos est pueros preferre puellis
msItem.explicit: Aut se dampnandos flammis et sulphure discant.

listBibl.bibl: Verses 1-4 printed from this manuscript in: E. Dümmler, 'Zur Sittengeschichte des Mittelalters', Zeitschrift für deutsches Altertum 22 (1878), p. 256.
A 16-verse variant is edited in: W. Wattenbach, 'Beschreibung einer Handschrift der Stadtbibliothek zu Reims', Neues Archiv 18 (1893), p. 519.

msItem.title: Planctus Oedipodis
msItem.incipit: Diri patris infausta pignora, ante ortus dampnati tempora
msItem.explicit: Cruciatus est ineffabilis, quem patimur gens miserabilis

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: W. Wattenbach, 'Die Klage des Oedipus', Zeitschrift für deutsches Altertum und deutsche Literatur 19 (1876), pp. 90-92; M. Esposito, 'Analecta varia. Part I', Hermathena 35 (1909), pp. 365-366.

msItem.title: Anti-feminist poem
msItem.incipit: Femina sordida, femina perdita, digna cathenis
msItem.explicit: quam mea sumere, uel mea tangere, sustineam te.

listBibl.bibl: Edited with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1428.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De mysterio missae
msItem.rubric: Hildebertus cenomanensis episcopus de canonice misse
msItem.incipit: Scribere proposui que mistica sacra priorum
msItem.explicit: Cum pater ad dextram cedit et explet opus.
msItem.note: The end of the poem is omitted.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: PL 171.1177–93.

msItem.title: De ordine missae
msItem.incipit: Missam beatus petrus apostolus primum fertur celebrasse antiochie
msItem.explicit: et ex hoc ad cunctas transiuit ecclesias.
msItem.note: A copy of the text is found in Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS. 265, pp. 440-442 (as recorded in M. Andrieu, Les ordines romani du haut moyen âge, vol. 1 (Louvain, 1931), pp. 99-101).

msItem.title: On the symbolism of mass
msItem.incipit: Prima sacerdotis statio ad dexteram altaris in principio misse significat rectitudinem
msItem.explicit: christo fideliter iuncti fulgebunt.

msItem.title: Epitaph of William Clito (d. 1128)
msItem.incipit: Mars obit in terris, deflent par sidera sidus
msItem.explicit: Occasus fuit hic sideris ortus ibi.
msItem.note: Attributed to Master Walo. On authorship: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. and trans. D. Greenway (Oxford, 1996), pp. 836-838; Sharpe, Handlist, pp. 156 and 707 (Master Walo); G. T. Beech, 'A Previously Unknown Loire Valley Monk (Saumur), Poet, and Bishop in Brittany, Galo († 1129)', Francia. Forschungen zur westeuropäischen Geschichte 46 (2019) pp. 49-75, at p. 68, n. 12.

listBibl.bibl: First two verses edited in: J. Werner, Beiträge zur Kunde der lateinischen Literatur des Mittelalters (Aarau, 1905), p. 40, no. 99.

Full poem edited, with comparison of different manuscripts, in: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. and trans. D. Greenway (Oxford, 1996), pp. 836-838.

msItem.title: Epitaph of pope Urban II?
msItem.incipit: Hic iuuenis lux urbis erat, defectus eclipsis
msItem.explicit: Suscipit inter nos nil nisi fama manet.

listBibl.bibl: A longer version of the poem (with two additional verses at the beginning, inc. 'Canonicus, Remensis Odo, quem Cluniacensis') was edited with the works of Orderic Vitalis in PL 188.178. See also PL 151.583.
WIC 8152 ('Hic vivens sol (lux) orbis erat defunctus eclipsis').
WIC 2368 ('Canonicus Remensis Odo, quem Cluniacensis').

extent.note: Signs of cropping on outer margins.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 27 lines. Ruled in leadpoint. Pricking on outer and lower margins. First line of text above the top ruled line. Fols. 94r-108r and 109v: irregular double vertical bounding lines on each side of the text, on most folios. Ruled space c. 86 3+ 48-56 +2
Fols. 108v-109r: single vertical bounding lines on each side of the text. Ruled space c. 90 69

handDesc.handNote: Early Gothic hands with some elements of documentary handwriting. The descenders of letters on the final lines are often elongated.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red painted initials, with green, red or black penwork (the penwork may be a later addition). Red stroke added to the first letter of each line on most pages.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De plagis Egipti (Carmina minora, no. 34)
msItem.incipit: Prima rubens unda rane tanesque secunda
msItem.explicit: nona tegit solem: primam necat ultima prolem.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 34 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 246.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Cur bono male vel malo bene (Carmina minora, no. 3)
msItem.incipit: Est aliquando bone bene ne grauibus superetur
msItem.explicit: Est male quo redeat, uel ut hic quoque iam patiatur.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 3 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 212.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Ad Petrum (Carmina minora, no. 2)
msItem.incipit: Susceptum semen sex primis, Petre, diebus
msItem.explicit: Effigiat, tempusque sequens augmentat in ortum

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 3 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 212.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De Roma (Carmina minora, no. 36)
msItem.incipit: Par tibi roma nichil cum sis prope tota ruina
msItem.explicit: uel dominis esset turpe carere fide.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 36.
M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 249.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De ermafrodito (Carmina minora, no. 23)
msItem.incipit: Dum mea me mater grauida gestaret in aluo
msItem.explicit: Uir, mulier, neutrum, flumina, tela, crucem.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 23 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 234.

msItem.title: Epitaph of Abelard
msItem.incipit: Pyeridum ter trina cohors elycone relicto
msItem.bibl: Cited in: A. B. Scott, 'The Poems of Hildebert of Le Mans: A New Examination of the Canon', Mediaeval and Renaissance Studies 6 (1968), pp. 42-83 at p. 49.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Ad Hugonem (Carmina minora, no. 8)
msItem.incipit: Si qua mihi scribis ne cuiquam scripta reuelem
msItem.explicit: Cum relegam nequeo scire quid ipsa uelint.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 8 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 216.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin (?) (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: Obscuros uersus facis hugo parumque latinos
msItem.explicit: Uel taceas: melius sic recitare soles.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: B. Hauréau, 'Notice sur les mélanges poétiques d'Hildebert de Lavardin', Notices et Extraits 28.2 (1878), p. 392; B. Hauréau, Les mélanges poétiques d'Hildebert de Lavardin (Paris, 1882), pp. 147-148.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Ad S. nepotem (Carmina minora, no. 33)
msItem.incipit: Res male tuta puer, ne te committe quibusdam
msItem.explicit: Mercedem culpe non dolet esse polum.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 33 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 245.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De Milone mercatore (Carmina minora, no. 7)
msItem.incipit: Milo domi non est. peregre milone profecto
msItem.explicit: Quo fodiatur ager non habet: uxor habet.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 7 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 215.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Ad Milonem (Carmina minora, no. 9)
msItem.incipit: Thura piper uestes argentum pallia uestes
msItem.explicit: Numquam uendentem deserit aut minuit.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 9 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 216.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Unde malum (Carmina minora, no. 5)
msItem.incipit: Qui petis unde malum cum sint bona cuncta cre[a]ta
msItem.explicit: Et per se citius dulcia poma trahunt.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 5 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 214.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De casu huius mundi (Carmina minora, no. 22)
msItem.incipit: Nuper eram locuples multisque beatus amicis
msItem.explicit: Quicquid uult in me digerat, eius ero.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 22 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 229.

msItem.incipit: Trax puer astricto glacie dum ludit in hebro
msItem.explicit: Hoc ppeperi flammis cetera dixit aquis.

listBibl.bibl: A variant is edited in Anthologia latina: sive poesis latinae supplementum. Pars prior: Carmina in codicibus scripta, Fasc. II, ed. A. Riese (Leipzig, 1870), pp. 159-160, no. 709.

msItem.title: Epitaph of Soranus
msItem.incipit: Ille ego pannoniis quondam notissimus horis
msItem.explicit: Exemplo mihi sum qui primus talia gessi.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Anthologia latina: sive poesis latinae supplementum. Pars prior: Carmina in codicibus scripta, Fasc. II, ed. A. Riese (Leipzig, 1870), p. 132, no. 660; Poetae latini minores, vol. 3, ed. E. Baehrens (Leipzig, 1882), p. 113.

msItem.incipit: Hec duo carta salus mihi nobis missa fuerunt
msItem.explicit: Ecce reportamus debita quisque sua.

listBibl.bibl: Printed from this manuscript in: Anexdota Oxoniensia. Texts, documents, and extracts chiefly from the Manuscripts in the Bodleian and other Oxford Libraries, Vol. I, Part V. Collatio cod. Harleiani 2610 Ovidii Metamorphoseon I, II, III. 1-622. Epigrammata latina XXIV ex codicibus Bodleianis et Sangallensibus. Glossae in Apollinarem Sidonium ex codice Digbeiano 172, ed. R. Ellis (Oxford, 1885), p. 24. Edited in: A. B. Scott, 'Some Poems attributed to Richard of Cluny', Medieval Learning and Literature. Essays presented to Richard William Hunt (Oxford, 1976), pp. 195-199, no. 5.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De quodam servo (Carmina minora, no. 24)
msItem.incipit: Seruus ait domino gratis famulabor in annum
msItem.explicit: Ne messem famuli sic emat ulterius.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 24 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 235.

msItem.incipit: Paruus erat limes quo presbiter ire solebat
msItem.explicit: Hanc fugat hunc iugulat huicque pudenda secat.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: B. Hauréau, Notices et extraits de quelques manuscrits de la Bibliothèque nationale, 1 (Paris, 1890), p. 236.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: Quid sit vita pudica (Carmina minora, no. 47)
msItem.incipit: In noctem prandes, in lucem turgide cenas
msItem.explicit: Uis dicam \quid/ sit uita pudica? modus.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 47 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces'. The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), p. 275.

msItem.author: Hildebert of Lavardin
msItem.title: De tribus vitiis: mulieri amore, avaritia, ambitione (Carmina minora, no. 50)
msItem.incipit: Plurima cum soleant mores euertere sacros
msItem.explicit: Fraude, cruore, dolis, mens, manus, ora uacant.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Hildebertus, Carmina minora, ed. A. B. Scott (Munich, Leipzig, 2001), no. 50 (manuscript L); M. Wolterbeek, 'The Gods Have Faces': The Biblical Epigrams and Short Poems of Hildebert of Lavardin (2024), pp. 279-282.

msItem.author: Ps.-Ausonius
msItem.title: Septem sapientum sententiae
msItem.incipit: Que nam summa boni? Que mens sibi conscia recti
msItem.explicit: Quid stulti proprium? Non posse et uelle nocere.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: C. Schenkl, MGH Auct. Ant. 5,2, pp. 246-247. See also PL 19.875.
Also edited with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1410 (Carmina miscellanea, no. 68).
R. Newhauser, I. Bejczy, A Supplement to Morton W. Bloomfield et al., 'Incipits of Latin Works on the Virtues and Vices, 1100-1500 A.D.' (Turnhout, 2008), p. 262, no. 4482.
A. G. Rigg, ‘Medieval Latin Poetic Anthologies (I)’, Mediaeval Studies 39 (1977), p. 300, no. 22.

msItem.incipit: Cherule tu cenas apud omnes nullus apud te
msItem.explicit: Dedecus est semper sumere, nilque dare

listBibl.bibl: Printed from this manuscript in: Anexdota Oxoniensia. Texts, documents, and extracts chiefly from the Manuscripts in the Bodleian and other Oxford Libraries, Vol. I, Part V. Collatio cod. Harleiani 2610 Ovidii Metamorphoseon I, II, III. 1-622. Epigrammata latina XXIV ex codicibus Bodleianis et Sangallensibus. Glossae in Apollinarem Sidonium ex codice Digbeiano 172, ed. R. Ellis (Oxford, 1885), p. viii. A four-verse variant is edited in Anthologia latina: sive poesis latinae supplementum. Pars prior: Carmina in codicibus scripta, Fasc. II, ed. A. Riese (Leipzig, 1870), p. xxx.
ICL, no. 2149.

msItem.incipit: Iuras dasque fidem tibi te nullam sociasse
msItem.explicit: Ergo pudicus eris, Neuole non sequitur.

listBibl.bibl: Printed from this manuscript in: Anexdota Oxoniensia. Texts, documents, and extracts chiefly from the Manuscripts in the Bodleian and other Oxford Libraries, Vol. I, Part V. Collatio cod. Harleiani 2610 Ovidii Metamorphoseon I, II, III. 1-622. Epigrammata latina XXIV ex codicibus Bodleianis et Sangallensibus. Glossae in Apollinarem Sidonium ex codice Digbeiano 172, ed. R. Ellis (Oxford, 1885), p. viii.
WIC 9965 (citing only this manuscript).

msItem.author: Martial
msItem.title: Epigrams, I, 97
msItem.incipit: Cum clamant omnis loqueris tunc neuole tantum
msItem.explicit: ecce tacent omnes, neuole dic aliquid

listBibl.bibl: Printed from this manuscript in: Anexdota Oxoniensia. Texts, documents, and extracts chiefly from the Manuscripts in the Bodleian and other Oxford Libraries, Vol. I, Part V. Collatio cod. Harleiani 2610 Ovidii Metamorphoseon I, II, III. 1-622. Epigrammata latina XXIV ex codicibus Bodleianis et Sangallensibus. Glossae in Apollinarem Sidonium ex codice Digbeiano 172, ed. R. Ellis (Oxford, 1885), p. viii.
ICL, no. 2990.

msItem.title: Epigram
msItem.incipit: Ut belli sonuere tube, uiolenta peremit
msItem.explicit: Argolicus theutras, marsus clonus, ybalus archas.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: A. Riese, Anthologia latina: sive poesis latinae supplementum. Pars prior: Carmina in codicibus scripta, Fasc. I (Leipzig, 1869), pp. 257-258, no. 392.

msItem.note: Further notes added (s. xiv?) in the space left blank at the end of fol. 116v ('Amen dico vobis super omnia bona sua. Dompnus abbas (...)').

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 25 lines. Ruled in leadpoint. Pricking on outer, lower and top margins. First line of text above the top ruled line. Irregular ruling pattern, with double bounding vertical lines on the right, and sometimes on the left. Ruled space c. 82 5+50+5 when there are double bounding vertical lines on both sides of the text.

handDesc.handNote: An early Gothic hand, sometimes irregular, with elements of documentary handwriting, such as slightly elongated ascenders. The descenders of letters on the final lines are often elongated.
Fol. 116v: additions in an informal hand with Anglicana features.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red painted initials, with red or black penwork (the penwork may be a later addition). Red stroke added to the first letter of each line on most pages.

msItem.incipit: Patrue pene pater, pater esto mihi sine pene
msItem.explicit: Est et erit tibi det quod cupis ipse dari.

listBibl.bibl: Printed from this manuscript in: C. Wollin, 'Sine uix und absque fere. Ein Beitrag zum Manierismus in der lateinischen Dichtersprache des 12. Jahrhunderts', Archivum Latinitatis Medii Aevi 72 (2014), pp. 129-186 at p. 185.
WIC 13841 and WIC 13751 ('Parve pene pater, pater esto mihi sine pene') (both citing only this manuscript).

msItem.author: Serlo of Bayeux
msItem.title: Defensio pro filiis presbyterorum
msItem.incipit: Rex immortalis quam longo tempore talis
msItem.explicit: Quoque modo scimus si nota referre uelimus

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: T. Wright, The Anglo-Latin satirical poets and epigrammatists of the twelfth century, vol. 2 (London, 1872), pp. 208-212; Defensio pro filiis presbyterorum, ed. H. Dümmler and H. Böhmer, in Libelli de lite imperatorum et pontificum, vol. 3 (Hannover, 1897) (MGH), pp. 580-583.

Cited in: E. Van Houts, 'The Fate of the Priests’ Sons in Normandy with Special Reference to Serlo of Bayeux', The Haskins Society Journal 25 (2013), pp. 57-106, at p. 83; E. Van Houts, 'Serlo of Bayeux and England', Tabularia, Autour de Serlon de Bayeux : la poésie normande aux XIe-XIIe siècles (2016); M.-A. Lucas-Avenel and E. D’Angelo, 'Vers une nouvelle édition des poèmes de Serlon de Bayeux', Tabularia : Sources écrites des mondes normands médiévaux (2017); E. D’Angelo, 'Enquête sur un poète au-dessus de tout soupçon : la production cachée de Serlon de Bayeux (I)', Revue d’Histoire des Textes 16 (2021), pp. 241-258.

msItem.incipit: Hunc numerare diem possim meliore lapillo
msItem.explicit: Sic pedis alterius iura terenda dedi.
msItem.note: The text includes extracts of classical poets, such as Ovid, Ars amatoria, I.40.

listBibl.bibl: WIC 8594 (citing only this manuscript).

msItem.incipit: Ad doctoris
msItem.explicit: Breues cibos, breuis mense, sibi
msItem.note: The text, in prose, includes a quote from Horace, Ars poetica (vv. 372-373: 'mediocribus esse poetis | non homines, non dii, non concessere columpne'), and a quote from Walther of Chatillon, Satire against the Curia (The Oxford Book of Medieval Latin Verse, ed. F. J. E. Raby (Oxford, 1959), no. 198, v. 32 ('Ipse licet ueniat musis comitatus, Homerus')).
Fols. 117-118 are blank, save for a note added (s. xiv?) on fol. 117v ('Fuit homo missus a Deo cui nomen').
Fol. 123 is blank and torn. Vertical rubrication at fol. 123r is not legible.

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 25 lines. Ruled in leadpoint. Pricking on outer and top margins. First line of text above the top ruled line. Irregular ruling pattern, with double bounding vertical lines on the right, and sometimes on the left. Ruled space c. 90 3 + 46-49 +3 (when there are double bounding vertical lines on both sides of the text)

handDesc.handNote: An early Gothic hand, sometimes irregular, with elements of documentary handwriting, such as slightly elongated ascenders. Some of the descenders of letters on the final lines are elongated. Fol. 117v: additions in an informal hand with Anglicana features.

decoDesc.decoNote: Red painted initials, with red or black penwork (the penwork may be a later addition).

msItem.author: Petrus Riga (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: Hactenus arrisit susanne gratia fame
msItem.explicit: Hec meruit titulos, hii meruere crucem.
msItem.note: The final two verses are not included in the printed editions.

listBibl.bibl: Edited with works of Hildebert, Archbishop of Tours in PL 171.1287. Edited in: B. Hauréau, Notices et Extraits 29.2, pp. 352-358 where it is attributed to Peter Riga. Edited in: Mozley, 'Susanna and the Elders: Three medieval poems', Studi medievali 3 (1930), pp. 27-52 at pp. 36-41 (poem 1a).

msItem.note: According to Beichner, the text belongs to a group of poems composed independently which circulated as part of Peter Riga's Floridus aspectus, and were later incorporated into his Aurora: Aurora: Petri Rigae Biblia versificata, ed. Beichner (Notre Dame, 1965), p. xv.

msItem.title: Poem on England
msItem.incipit: Istic inuenies uenalia tanta quod omnes
msItem.explicit: Terminat hora diem, terminat auctor opus.
msItem.note: Imperfect at the beginning. The final 16 verses of the poem are copied at the top of fol. 130r, and fols. 128v-129v were left blank.

listBibl.bibl: The poem, beginning 'Ibis et in nostros', was edited in: W. Wattenbach, 'Verse aus England', Neues Archiv (1876), p. 602 (poem no. 3); A. B. Scott, 'Some Poems attributed to Richard of Cluny', Medieval Learning and Literature. Essays presented to Richard William Hunt (Oxford, 1976), pp. 195-199 (manuscript La).
WIC 8644 ('Ibis et in nostros, dives Londonia, versus').

msItem.author: Hugo Primas (attrib.)
msItem.incipit: In cratere meo thetis est sociata lyeo
msItem.explicit: Hec duo, propterea sit deus absque dea.
msItem.note: Only the first 4 verses are included.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: The Oxford Poems of Hugh Primas and the Arundel Lyrics, ed. C. J. McDonough (Toronto, 1984), no. 14; Carmina Burana, No. 194 (1/3. 28–31) (manuscript O1).

msItem.note: On attribution: A. G. Rigg, ‘Golias and other Pseudonyms’, Studi Medievali (1977), p. 97.

msItem.title: A collection of proverbs extracted from the Ysengrimus
msItem.incipit: Ille ubi cassa fides ruit in discrimina casus
msItem.explicit: Plebs procerum cibus est, utpote prata gregum.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Ysengrimus, ed. E. Voigt (Halle a. S., 1884). Translation in English: Ysengrimus. Text with translation, commentary and introduction, ed. and trans. J. Mann (Leiden, 1987); Ysengrimus, ed. and trans. J. Mann (Cambridge, Massachusetts, London, 2013).

msItem.note: A full discussion is in preparation by the cataloguer.

msItem.title: Poem to Saint Anselm? (Quarto Catalogue)
msItem.incipit: Uir felix sanctus uirtutis nomine tantus

listBibl.bibl: WIC 20398 (citing only this manuscript).

msItem.incipit: Suspice me miserum
Rex regalis honor laus rerum gloria regum

msItem.author: Robert Partes
msItem.title: Poem on Thomas Becket (extract: verses on London)
msItem.incipit: Nobilis, ampla, potens, urbs urbibus anteferenda
msItem.explicit: Indiga nullius, martire martir ouat

listBibl.bibl: The poem (inc.: 'Cor gemit, auris hebet, manus aret, linga rigescit') was edited in: W. H. Cornog, 'The Poems of Robert Partes', Speculum 12 (1937), pp. 215-250, at p. 248-249.
WIC 11832 (citing only this manuscript).

msItem.title: Obituary for Queen Matilda, first wife of King Henry I
msItem.incipit: Prospera non letam fecere nec aspera tristem
msItem.explicit: Raptam perpetuam fecit inesse diem

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. and trans. D. Greenway, Book vii. 30, p. 462. See also William Camden, Remaines concerning Britaine (London, 1636), p. 321 (only 4 verses).

msItem.title: Poem in honour of King Henry I's victory at Brémule in 1119
msItem.incipit: Henricus regum rex et decus abstulit altos
msItem.explicit: Oraque francorum mutire superba coegit.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. and trans. D. Greenway, Book vii. 31, p. 464.

msItem.title: Poem in honour of Queen Adeliza, second wife of King Henry I
msItem.incipit: Anglorum regina tuos adeliza decores
msItem.explicit: Nec pudeat dominam te precor esse meam.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. and trans. D. Greenway, Book vii. 33, p. 468.

msItem.title: Epitaph of Robert Bloet, bishop of Lincoln
msItem.incipit: Pontificum robertus honor quem fama superstes
msItem.explicit: Liquid, et euigilans uera perhenne uidit.

listBibl.bibl: Edited in: Henry, Archdeacon of Huntingdon: Historia Anglorum. The History of the English People, ed. and trans. D. Greenway, Book vii. 34, p. 470. The epitaph also appears in Book xi. 11, with a variant line 6 (also in: T. Wright, The Anglo-Latin Satirical Poets and Epigrammatists of the Twelfth Century vol. 2 (London, 1872), p. 168).

layoutDesc.layout: 1 col., 23-26 lines. Ruled in leadpoint. First line of text above the top ruled line. Irregular double vertical bounding lines on each side of the text, on most folios. Ruled space c. 80-86 4+54+3

handDesc.handNote: Several hands. An early Gothic hand, sometimes irregular, with elements of documentary handwriting, such as slightly elongated ascenders. Some of the descenders of letters on the final lines are elongated. Fol. 133r: a feature of style on the ascender of the letter 's' on the top line.
Fols. 132v-133v: Additions; an irregular Northern textualis.

decoDesc.decoNote: One red painted initial, with green penwork (fol. 124r) (the penwork may be a later addition).

revisionDesc.change: James Cummings Up-converted the markup using https://github.com/jamescummings/Bodleian-msDesc-ODD/blob/master/convertTolkien2Bodley.xsl
